Problem:
Consider a system where the temperature distribution \\( u(x,t) \\) in a rod is described by the heat equation \\( u_t = ku_{xx} \\), where \\( k \\) is the thermal diffusivity constant. We examine the influence of an external heat source \\( q(x,t) \\) modeled by the transformation \\( f(u) = u + q(x,t) \\).

If \\( f(u) \\) is applied to the initial temperature distribution \\( u(x,0) \\) and allowed to evolve under \\( u_t = ku_{xx} \\) without further intervention, will \\( u(x,T) \\) at a later time T be the same as if \\( u(x,0) \\) was directly evolved to time T under \\( u_t = ku_{xx} \\)?
Explanation: Applying the transformation \\( f(u) \\) modifies the initial temperature distribution by adding \\( q(x,0) \\). This modifies the initial conditions of the heat equation, thus altering the temperature distribution at time T from what would have been obtained had \\( u(x,0) \\) been evolved without the addition of \\( q(x,t) \\). The heat evolution is sensitive to initial conditions.
